0553213105|5.0|I'm ashamed to admit it, but I only picked this up after watching the latest excellent BBC adaptation of Jane Austen's now-ubiquitous 'Pride and Prejudice'.<br />Let me preface this review by saying that this is a novel like no other - it's Little Women with Declaritive Sentences, it's Gone With The Wind without the Overstatement. The story of the five Bennett sisters in their quest to make good marriages is as entertaining as it is relevant, and Austen's acerbic and subtle humour still shine today.<br />Eliza Bennett has a problem. She is the only independant sister in a family of five girls, ruled by a weatherbeaten Father and a hyperactive Mother. She wishes to marry for love, and love alone, but times are hard, and if she does not marry for money, she will be poor, as her father's estate is entailed away to his only nephew, the connsumately hideous Clergyman, Mr. Collins. She meets and falls in immediate Hate with the snobbish, upper-class Mr. Darcy, and through a series of mishaps, revelations and balls, she discovers that he is not the man she first suspected him to be.<br />Austen shows an almost unnatural intelligence with her prose. She is the definitive social commentator, and slips her jokes and judgements into her writing with such subtlety, that you forget she's doing it at all. Unlike Louisa M. Alcott's heavy-handed Christian-Morals littered about 'Little Women', Austen's morals are of a markedly more subtle nature. Truly ahead of her time, and an early feminist, her writing advocates independance for women, and shows clearly the faults and idiosyncrasies of men and silly women - a refreshing change for the period. Even today, her caustic protrayals of Mrs. Bennett, a woman as mercenary in her dealings with marriage as she is socially embarrassing, Lady Catherine DeBourgh, a wealthy, if somewhat inbred, dowager, and Mr. Collins, a greasy and truly venal human being, ring true as vivid and relevant descriptions of how to be an Idiot. The opposite can besaid of her central character, Elizabeth Bennett. Clearly a semi-autobiographical heroine, Austen has created in Eliza an independant and intelligent heroine, but tempers this with several character flaws (the most notable being the titular 'Pride') to produce a young woman of believable depth and character.<br />Her plot is long-winded and drawn-out, but, thanks to Austen's wonderful gift for making characters interesting as well as whole, it never once loses pace; instead, it becomes a joy to read. Her Cast Of Thousands each have a distinct part to play in uniting Elizabeth with her true love, and however small that part, Austen ensures they do it with memorable gusto.<br />All in all, I urge everyone to read this novel. However, I think it's best read after seeing the TV adaptations, because while good, they cannot even begin to show the depth and intelligence of this novel. You'll appreciate Austen all the more after 'Pride and Prejudice'.
B00000DRXW|5.0|20 some years later and I still remember the first night I heard this CD for the first time, like it was yesterday. And after 20 years I still get goose-bumps every time I listen to this CD. Anyone who loves guitar has to have this CD. But how they play together and play off each other is mind blowing! Guitar lovers prepare for 40 minutes of heaven.

B00006G8G1|5.0|I have &quot;discovered&quot; Iron Maiden this year. Heard only a few songs over the years and was generally unmoved. However, having reacquainted myself with them I am duly impressed.<br />The Rock in Rio DVD is not perfect, with, as mentioned earlier, sometimes dizzying changes in camera angles. Have to give Steve Harris credit though, he does give everyone a fair exposure, and you really don't mind the changes.<br />To me, a live performance is where the rubber hits the road. No studio magic, overdubs or computer tracking. You either have it nailed or you perish. Sure, sometimes live performance recording is lacking in sound or video perfection, but do you expect that when you see someone live?<br />The musicianship of Maiden is top notch. Not just an average metal band. Complicated and difficult tempos, tasteful key changes, great lead guitar spread equally between Janick Gers and Dave Murray, with Adrian Smith laying down the crunching bottom end with deafening riffs. Steve Harris is a little annoying with his constant &quot;foot on the monitor&quot; poses and lip synching of Bruce Dickinsons singing, but, cut Steve some slack, he is the main songwriter of this band and displays some credible talent in this aspect. He wrote 70 songs after all.<br />Bruce Dickinson doesn't falter an inch. His pipes are clean and crisp with good energy. Nico McBrain is great, laying down the drum lines which bring the other players together to create some memorable songs, ie. &quot;Sign of the Cross&quot;. You try playing that song on your guitar, bass or drums. ha. not!<br />The best things I like about Iron Maiden is that they are my age, and they can rock better than the talent that are dotting the rock/metal scene these days. No comparisons. (Well, Metallica is coming back to their roots).<br />I find myself collecting DVDs now that display the ever- disappearing talent from the groups of the 60's through the 80's. Clapton, Stevie Ray, Deep Purple, Queen, Pink Floyd, Black Sabbath. Zepplin,  and now, Maiden.<br />Yeah, I know, its from my era, but really, where is the talent now compared to the bands from that time period?<br />Sum 41? Blink 182? Linkin Park?..... I don't think so.<br />Rock on Iron Maiden, and thanks!ath. B000068PQ0|5.0|2002 brought the Year of Yoshimi to the Lips and more critical accolades. Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots takes a look at what it means to be human in our current mechanized age and our relation, man and machine, to the universe. Though a much lighter and optimistic release than The Soft Bulletin, it remains nonetheless prescient in our world. Yoshimi opens with \\"Fight Test\\" with Lips' frontman Wayne Coyne examining what is worth fighting for, and how far should we take things in this life. The contrast between the lyrical content and traditional pop structure of this song with the electronic noises interspersed throughout speaks to this dichotomy of living in the mechanized age as it questions what we should do for ourselves, and what we should have others, be they machines or humans, do for us. Of course, I've always felt that \\"Fight Test\\" and its singsong melody was ironically a banjo away from being a classic country tune. \\"One More Robot/Symphony 3000-21\\" looks at the human/machine contrast more directly with it's chorus, \\"One more robot learns to be / Something more than a machine / When it tries the way it does / Makes it seem like it can love.\\" Guided along by a hypnotic bass line melody, various vocal effects continue this throughout the song sounding as if it is a love song to the robot itself from its human creator closing with rather heavenly synth keyboard and harp effects. Humanity has become infatuated with our creations, their gifts, and ability to mimic human life. \\"Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots pt. 1\\" continues in the singsong vein of \\"Fight Test.\\" Beginning with an almost start-stop variation on the track's melody, here we have humanity taking the robots head-on. Personified as humanity, Yoshimi's decided that we are worth fighting for \\"so she's taking lots of vitamins / cause she knows that it'd be tragic if those evil robots win.\\" The mechanization of \\"One More Robot\\"'s bass line has been replaced with a simple guitar strum, a deep kick drum,and more pointed synth effects. The instrumental \\"Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots pt. 2\\" follows with Yoshimi's screams dominating the bulk of the track following the falling bass notes of the melody. She struggles to make it through all the background noise and voices getting in the way of her attempts to make it to the fore mix of the track. Is Yoshimi victorious? Has she lost the race for the prize? Have we lost to our own \\"evil-natured robots programmed to destroy us?\\" <br />\\"In the Morning of the Magicians\\" may hold the answer to those questions, or does it? Opening up in a sleepy haze questioning \\"what is love and what is hate / the calculations error,\\" the track slowly builds as the \\"dawn began to break\\" with Yoshimi surrendering to the universe \\"too powerful to master.\\" It seems we have been defeated by our own devices. \\"Ego Tripping at the Gates of Hell\\" reveals that humanity has in fact defeated itself in hopes that these machines would love us as Coyne sings \\"I was wanting you to love me / But your love it never came / All the other love around me / Was just wasting all away.\\" We've gotten so focused on our struggle with becoming more \\"advanced\\" by increasing the mechanization and automation of society, that we lost all sight, touch, and love, of each other. The realization of this loss and the increasing distance comes into focus with \\"Are You a Hypnotist??\\" as we realize \\"I am a stranger now amongst all the recognized / What is this? / Are you some kind of hypnotist??\\" We've become hypnotized by our creations, our machines, and our ability to create these beasts that we've darkened what is truly important, each other, with \\"the sun eclipse behind the cloud.\\" \\"It's Summertime (Throbbing Orange Pallbearers)\\" recognizes the sadness of this event, with its strange mix of musical optimism and malaise, as we're left only seeing a \\"self-reflected inner sadness\\" as the throbbing orange pallbearers rise and fall with the day. \\"Do You Realize??\\" opens with a digitally altered voice and one of the most simplest and stunning lyrics in all of pop music: \\"Do you realize / That you have the most beautiful face??\\" Apparently humanity has won, we felt the loss of our brother in the previous two tracks and we're all just part of the universe's big master plan, the machines, us, all of us, and how infinitely small we are in comparison to that which is beyond our comprehension. The booming gong, slightly echoed guitar, and airy vocals create an otherworldly effect showing our relationship to the universe. Despite this realization of our minute scale to the grand scheme of things, there is still hope and \\"everyone you know someday will die / and instead of saying all of your goodbyes / let them know you realize that life goes fast / it's hard to make the good things last / you realize the sun doesn't go down / it's just an illusion caused by the world spinning round.\\" \\"All We Have Is Now\\" shows the effects of this postrealization and teaches us how we should act, \\"you and me were never meant to be part of the future / all we have is now / all we've ever had was now,\\" and with that, we've come to terms that we should live for today, live for ourselves, live for each other, live for love. Tomorrow might never come, don't worry about improving the machines for coming generations, don't worry about improving tomorrow; improve yourself for today. Closing the disc is the instrumental (and Grammy-winning) \\"Approaching Pavonis Mons by Balloon (Utopia Planitia)\\" as we glide along above looking back on it all, the trumpets blare with pride and joy of our newfound love for ourselves, each other, and the world.<br />Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots is one of the masterpieces of our time and a work that while the songs themselves are instantly hummable, the grand themes of take a little longer to enjoy. Perhaps it might take a universe of time to achieve full comprehension of Yoshimi's aims, but we don't have that time, we've got forty-seven and one-half minutes, so we must do with it what we can.

In some ways Amy Lee's voice sounds similar: sweet, mellow and vulnerable.  <br />Hopefully Evanescence will be able to follow up with more great albums.  Other bands with sudden fame could never come close to their debuts like Dishwalla and 3 Doors Down.  Evanescance has a good range.  The music flows from dark, quiet piano and vocal pieces like Hello and My Immortal to the all-out rock of Going Under and Bring Me To Life, and everything in between like Taking Over Me and My Last Breath.  <br />If all goes well they will realize the advantage they have of exploring all of these styles and they won't fall into the trap of choosing to play only pop or only rock.

B000065VA1|4.0|&quot;So&quot; is the most upbeat and optimistic-sounding of all of Peter Gabriel's albums--Genesis included--and contains his most commercial set of songs, so it's no wonder why it remains the overwhelming favorite among critics and listeners to this day.<BR>For those who are attracted to PG's darker, artier works, however, &quot;So&quot; may sound like a heavily manicured piece of pop fluff, drowned in (to these ears) dated 80s production values<BR>and featuring some songs (&quot;Sledgehammer&quot; and &quot;Big Time&quot;) so far removed from Gabriel's actual musical style that this is probably as close as he came to the term &quot;sell-out&quot;.<br />Nonetheless, Gabriel's genius is such that the album does not emerge as a total washout.  &quot;Red Rain&quot; is a graceful, richly melodic track that anchors the beginning of the album, while both &quot;Mercy Street&quot; and &quot;We Do What We're Told&quot; are quiet, haunting and infused with world-music touches (&quot;Mercy Street&quot; remains one of my favorite songs, actually).  The production on these is simpler and therefore less grating than on such light confections as &quot;Sledgehammer&quot; and &quot;In Your Eyes&quot;, which aren't terrible (who can deny the catchiness of either tune?) but the 80s dance-pop sound captured here simply does not remind one of the &quot;real&quot; Gabriel captured on &quot;The Lamb&quot;, &quot;Solsbury Hill&quot;, &quot;San Jacinto&quot; or &quot;Passion&quot;; ironically, their popularity is so overwhelming that most fans continue to primarily identify him with these two tracks (FWIW, the extended 7-minute version of &quot;In Your Eyes&quot; is superior to the album cut).  Elsewhere, we have the uplifting ballad &quot;Don't Give Up&quot; (one of the better cuts and again very popular, although I'll take &quot;Blood Of Eden&quot; over this any day), more 80s dance hits like &quot;Big Time&quot; and <BR>a reject from the abandoned &quot;Mozo&quot; concept, &quot;That Voice Again&quot;. <BR>Overall, &quot;So&quot; remains a must-purchase, if only to hear what the fuss is about.  Nearly every song has achieved popularity, which to some makes it a very consistent album.  But for those fans who want the darker, edgier, stuff, only &quot;Red Rain&quot;, &quot;Mercy Street&quot; and &quot;We Do What We're Told&quot; will satisfy this time around.  &quot;Us&quot; would mark a superior mix of his commercial and artistic sides, with that &quot;big 80s&quot; production (the headache-inducing drum machines, dance rhythms and metallic reverb) muffled or absent.

B00005JMJ4|2.0|This is a story told from the point of view of a shockingly self-obsessed girl who finds her poor li'l ol' self stranded in Tokyo Japan. Her hatred for women is shown to us (through her first-person eyes) as a parade of moderately retarded bimbos and an occasional prostitute, punctuated by a sweetheart of a man who is, of course, the victim of yet another bitchy woman. Even this sweetheart (played by Bill Murray) is portrayed as virtuous in precisely only those instances where his interests intersect with the interests of our neglected Princess.<br />Our poor protagonist has a husband who, like the other women in the movie, is written to be stupid, cardboard, insensitive and prone to inexplicable fits of protracted misunderstanding. Our Princess is also written to have a degree in philosophy and a penchant for knitting - both tokens of *depth* as prop-ish as the hotel wallpaper only more contrived and not as pretty. The racist elements of the movie are shown against the backdrop of a hip soundtrack. The soundtrack wins, giving the audience the moral permission to laugh without feeling boorish.<br />Long, tedious shots of the winsome girl staring out her hotel window at the sprawling city - which to her is merely a mosaic painted on the window of her hotel/prison - mean to give us a sense of her emotional despair. The cure, Gobs of Attention, is disguised in more palatable forms for ticketholders. Even a trip to the Buddhist temple doesn't move her. Hadn't anyone warned her that monks don't fawn? But the requisite Gobs of Attention eventually come from Murray and this almost makes Princess happy.<br />Of course this dismal story is told from the perspective of the dismal Princess - consequently, the retarded bimbo, cardboard boyfriend, me-so-hoe-nee prostitute, bucktoothed Japanese folk and all the rest of her projections are submitted as \\"givens\\" in the screenplay. Her self-obsession is absent from her self-awareness and is therefore absent from the surface of the script, and so forth. What we get is a view of the world from \\"behind the eyes\\" of a Spoiled Snot who doesn't realize that's what she's letting us see. The view? Pretty damned lonely. We're supposed to blame this on her various projections. Some moviegoers actually do. They're the ones who click \\"NO\\" on Was-This-Review-Helpful?<br />By the time Princess receives her panacea, the audience has been bludgeoned into submission and says \\"Thank you sir\\" for a spoonful of some mighty thin gruel. Tears and cheers are finally milked from the teenage girls. Then the credits roll.<br />Bill Murray is outstanding, nonetheless.<br />Ms. Copolla uses this movie to show us how she would like us to see her - which is different from how she sees herself - which is also different from how she actually IS.script, and so forth. 6304696566|5.0|John Wayne plays the anti-hero Ethan Edwards who returns undefeated and unrepentant three years after the defeat of the Confederacy to the family ranch in Texas.  Soon after his arrival the ranch is raided by Commanches, the family murdered and Ethans young niece is kidnapped.  The rest of the movie portrays Ethans five-year quest for his niece. <br />In a real sense, Ethans search for his niece is reminisence of  Melvilles Moby Dick.  The relentless pursuit of the white whale represents not only Ahabs vengeance against the animal for taking his leg, but also an attempt to pursue and defeat the God who allowed this misfortune to happen.   Thus, Ahab abandons all reason in his monomaniacal thirst for revenge.  The chase becomes more than a whaling story for in killing Moby Dick Ahab is avenging himself against God; but in the end Ahab and his crew perishes before the White God.   Compare this to Ethans monomaniacal pursuit to kill Scarface, the chief who lead the raiding party that killed Ethans family and to rescue his niece.  Ethan abandons reason and gives into blind hatred- shooting the eyes out of a dead Indian, taking parting shots at retreating Indians when everyone else has stopped firing, killing the buffalo so Indian families will starve and threatening to kill his own niece who has been defiled by the Indians. This is more than a search and rescue mission- it is Ethans attempt to come to grips with the defeat of the Confederacy, to gain victory where he has only known defeat.  It is more than a story of vengeance.  It is a story of a man facing his prejudice and blind hatred of the Indians. Ethan does not directly battle God, but he battles the inner demons that plague him. In the end, unlike Ahab, he finds redemption.  He rescues his niece and as the family enters the home to celebrate the reunion, Ethan turns and leaves.  He is alone, but he is at peace with himself.
B000002MZ9|4.0|8 years later, this CD holds up brilliantly. Young was certainly intoxicated by the breath of fresh, extremely competent and challenging musicianship that Pearl Jam offered him, much as he was by the power trio of the FREEDOM CD. How much Crazy Horse can one man take? In any case, as a band, not just a leader with a pack of bungling sidekicks, Young and Pearl Jam deliver one of the best CDs of his career. There are some truly great numbers here: \\"Peace and Love\\", \\"I'm the Ocean\\" (which would resurface on GREENDALE as \\"Be the Rain\\"), \\"Throw Your Hatred Down\\" (which resonates more profoundly given the current geo-political crises) are absolutely classic Young songs on a level with \\"Hurricane\\" and \\"Powderfinger\\". The throwaway cut here is \\"Downtown,\\" which at the time was the \\"hit.\\" He needs to lay off anything that might even suggest Danny Whitten.<BR>The rest is amazing stuff and seems to suggest that in the effort to somehow validate ourselves via the fetishization fans embrace for rock stars, or for that matter any icon of the cult of personality, we lose sight of what is so precious about our own lives, become tranfixed and mesmerized by the glittering lights bouncing off the mirror ball. Extend that to a national scope and it becomes a pandemic of nationalistic narcissism, which of course begets the cultural wars fed by isolationist persecution complexes.Well, maybe I'm reading a bit into this. Truth is, there was a time Young could inspire you to think. Anyway, for those who just want to rock and roll, this will do it for you. Young would find additional inspiration in his return to Crazy Horse, although his return to CSN would actual deaden his focus. The guy who eschewed the pop stardom of HARVEST, would somehow seek it out at the end of the nineties. At this point, though, Neil was firing on all burners and this is a great, great testament to a songwriter justifying his reputation.
B0000CEB4V|5.0|An extraordinary concert - musically, sonically, and visually. I started it at 11pm on the night of the blizzard, thinking I'd just start it, watch the best bits, and continue the next day.  But I couldn't stop watching. This is a concert for the ages.<br />First, for those of us who have never adapted to the MTV geenration's style of quick cuts and multiple angles, it's a pleasure to see camerawork with long slow cuts, intelligently placed. You get a &quot;you are there&quot; experience. From the musicans' point of view on stage, through extraordinary &quot;overview&quot; shots of this gorgeous hall. Sonically, the mix is sensational. If you see/hear this concert projected in a &quot;home theater&quot; environment with a fine 5.1 system you will be very, very pleased. Every instrument is clearly placed, there is a rock solid bass, vocals are up front, close your eyes and you can still &quot;see it&quot;. But you really need to see the visual images of these guys to appreciate the music they made. For many of us, these are our contemporary rock heroes. And for many, there is no hiding the years that have passed.<br />It opens with Eric Clapton's noble introduction (apparantly edited to omit his mistaken reference to &quot;George's wife Dhani&quot; the latter being his son. (Paul McC. later reminded him of his mistake on stage - tacky Sir Paul, very tacky.  This too, has been editted out) An aged Ravi Shanker  - looking very much like the village wise man in Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom - opens the concert along with his daughter, seque-ing into a beautiful &quot;The Inner Light&quot; sung by Jeff Lyne. Beautiful. The suite of indian music composed for the occasion sets the tone nicely. His closing uke sing-a-long I'll See You In My Dreams will bring tears to your eyes (especially when you see the falling flower petals which accompany it on the DVD)  Ringo  is in fine voice but just a wee bit TOO jovial, thin as a rail, 60s velveteen jacket, constant peace signs, and bouncing and conducting.  Maybe it was nerves.  Everyone else is superb - particularly the magisterial Billy Preston, Eric clapton, and of course, &quot;Our Jeff&quot; Lynn. B00008J4P5|4.0|I liked this album. The guitar playing is raw, the drumming is loud, the vocals are delightfully abrasive, and the bass is, of course, missing. But The White Stripes have a way of making you not miss that latter. The first few times through &quot;Elephant&quot; is a great listen. The songs are catchy and energetic with enough gritty production to trick you into thinking that &quot;Elphant&quot; is as indie as they come. <br />The problems with &quot;Elephant&quot; is two-fold. The first is, upon multiple listens, it's easy to tell that the album lacks much cohesion. The transition between songs like You've Got Your Hand in Her Pocket and Ball and Biscuit; and Girl, You Have No Faith in Medicine and It's True that We Love One Another are questionable. <br />The second is that there isn't much on Elephant that I haven't heard before on previous albums. Elephant might be an elaboration upon their previous work, but it's definitely not a progression. Not that that is a bad thing. Elephant is a very accessible album, perhaps making it good for new fans of the Stripes. Elephant is also most things a good rock album should be: raw and energetic and powerful, and one can only hope that this album will be the gateway that leads many pop and nu-metal fans into the realm of real rock.
B000000W5B|4.0|Indeed!   But after Beggar's Banquet, Let It Bleed, Ya-Ya's, Sticky Fingers, and Exile...what the **** COULD they do to follow all THAT up?  Well, despite all the naysayers, this is a FINE, fine piece of music, and, yeah, I am prejudiced, because Mick Taylor and Bill Wyman were still members and Ian Stewart was still there.  OK, that being said, let's look at some of the songs:  I gotta admit, I was a mite...leary of the first track, &quot;Dancing With Mr. D,&quot; because I said, &quot;Uh-oh, Anita's got Keef into this satan **** too heavily.&quot;  And, OF course, Keef, played right INTO that accusation by playing one of the most stink-finger guitar intros ever to open the album.  It wasn't until some years later that I was...enlightened to the fact that the whole album was a sort of &quot;in joke&quot; about Mick fooling around with Angela, David Bowie's wife.  I mean, dig: what's the big hit of the album? Yup, &quot;Angie.&quot;  Musically now, &quot;Dancing&quot; has an amazing bass line, and I can't ascertain whether it's Bill Wyman or Mick Taylor playing it.  Keef's obviously not on the next track, &quot;100 Years Ago,&quot; but, for once, despite his absence, it's a great track.  Billy Preston was - and still IS - a magnificant keyboard player.  Keef, however, DOES show up on the next song, &quot;Comin' Down Again&quot; - fact is, he sings one of his all too rare lead vocals on it.  &quot;Heartbreaker/Doo Doo Doo Doo Doo&quot; is a STOMPER, with some rather grim lyrics about overdosing.  About ten years later, Bryan Adams would rip the chord progression off for &quot;Take Me Back,&quot; which was about the best thing HE ever did. (check it out!) &quot;Angie&quot; was beautiful, yeah - and it made a GREAT video with Keef about to fall over his guitar! - but I'm like Mick, I tend to want to get &quot;love songs&quot; over &amp; out of the way quickly.  &quot;Silver Train&quot; is a track they'd written for Johnny Winter, and truth is, neither of them did it worth a durn, except Mick Taylor displays just WHY the Stones were at their peak while he was with them.  As a slide guitar player, he is one of the best, EVER.  &quot;Hide Your Love&quot; is another stomper, this time with Mick playing piano. The next two tracks, despite differing titles, &quot;Winter&quot; and &quot;Can You Hear The Music,&quot; are basically the same song.  BUT THEY SAVED THE VERY BEST FOR LAST!  I'm certain everybody, by now, has heard about Mick &quot;just stamping his little feet, he was so mad&quot; with Ahmet Ertegun about having to rather...&quot;sanitize&quot; the song title.  Just as well, WE knew what he was talking about. And once you hear that &quot;Keef's channeling Chuck Berry&quot; intro with Mick whining &quot;Baby, Ah ben' so sad since you been gawn,&quot; you know you and the Stones are back on terra firma.  Ian Stewart, of course, shines, and, despite the fact that the results were sorta anti-climatic, I'm grateful that the CD cleans up that bit of sludge toward the end of the second verse.  &quot;Goat's Head Soup&quot; - well, what else were you listening to at the time?

B000000OQF|4.0|Although Guns N' Roses are now looked upon in a different light now than in 1987, thanks to lead singer Axl Rose's nosedive into becoming a passive-aggressive, arrogant, self-centered, and childish ego monster, there was a time when the band made great music together.  Along with now-legendary guitarist Slash, Izzy Stradlin (guitar), Duff McKagen (bass), and original drummer Steve Adler, GN'R gave late-'80s hard rock a much-needed punch in the gut with their blistering debut album APPETITE FOR DESTRUCTION.  Though it's not quite the classic that many repute it to be, it still stands head and shoulders above any of the mindless, faceless &quot;hair rock&quot; that was going on around that era.  If you looked at their pictures, GN'R looked just like another hair band, but their music was much more real, rawer, and in your face than those groups.  This sounds like something Aerosmith or the Rolling Stones would do in the '70s, not Poison or Ratt.<br />Everybody knows the singles &quot;Welcome to the Jungle,&quot; &quot;Paradise City,&quot; and &quot;Sweet Child o' Mine&quot; since they helped launch the album to multi-platinum mega-success.  Out of these three songs, &quot;Sweet Child o' Mine&quot; still holds up the best and sounds great even today.  The same can't be said for the former two; too much radio airplay and MTV rotation have damaged those songs in my opinion.  What makes APPETITE a great record are the obscure album tracks.  My favorite song is &quot;My Michelle,&quot; a scorching riff monster that starts out very pretty like a Led Zeppelin tune but quickly turns into a menacing tale of a girl from the wrong side of the tracks.  Other riff-heavy and relentless rockers include the paranoid &quot;Out ta Get Me,&quot; the bluesy shuffle &quot;Mr. Brownstone&quot; (about a drug dealer), the very catchy and melodic &quot;Think About You,&quot; and the fierce closer &quot;Rocket Queen.&quot;<br />This album is definitely one to bang your head to since every songrocks hard from beginning to end, but it's not entirely great.  &quot;It's So Easy,&quot; &quot;You're Crazy,&quot; and &quot;Anything Goes&quot; are juvenile tunes that should've been scraped (ironically, the acoustic version of &quot;You're Crazy&quot; is surprisingly better), and &quot;Nightrain&quot; goes on for far too long, even for a 4 minute song.  Kudos though for producer Mike Clink and his mixing team, for which the album sounds raw and rugged like a '70s record, and not overly polished like most of the rock records were at the time.<br />Though not a perfect album, APPETITE FOR DESTRUCTION did indeed bring the true essence back to rock &amp; roll and purified it for the next generation up until a certain point.  On a sidenote, Slash, Duff McKagen, and second GNR drummer Matt Sorum recently reunited this year and have teamed up with former STP frontman Scott Weiland to form a new band called Velvet Revolver.  They released their first song &quot;Set Me Free&quot; on the HULK soundtrack and will release their debut in 2004.  Be on the lookout for that.  Can't say the same for Axl, who's probably wallowing in his past.  Oh well...

Just sit and listen to the melodies and the lyrics, it's an incredible album.

B00008J4P5|5.0|A lot of folks have noted that rock and roll is in a bit of decline.  Fewer and fewer truly great bands have made their appearance in recent years, and for every Radiohead or Wilco or Thea Gilmore or Strokes or Hives there are literally hundreds of bands that either sound derivative, uninspired, or forgettable.  At times, I have worried if rock and roll was something that belonged more to the fifties, sixties, seventies, and eighties than to the present and future.<br />But then, when I am feeling despondent about the future of rock and roll, a band like White Stripes comes along and unpacks a passel of songs that don't sound entirely like anything else that has been done in rock, and yet sounds as vital, energized, and irreverent as anything else that has come along.  On a total pernicious level, one could compare them with the Carpenters.  Well, both were brother-sister bands.  In the one, the sister played drums and sang, while the brother wrote the songs, sang back up, and played piano, while in the new band the sister plays drums and sings, and the brother writes the songs, sings, and plays devastating guitar.  Well, OK, the Carpenters's music defines &quot;suck&quot; and the White Stripes play blistering rock, but I still love the bizarre parallel.<br />The White Stripes are definitely rock minimalists, in the purest sense of having minimal instrumentation.  But truth be told there is nothing terribly minimal about their sound.  How such a small band generates so much sound is really remarkable.<br />I liked this album so much I went back and sampled some of their earlier albums, and found them to be nearly a fine, in particular WHITE BLOOD CELLS and DE STIJL.  With three very good albums behind them, they have to be accounted one of the very best bands in the world.<br />And at least temporarily, my hope in the future of rock and roll is bolstered.
0789723107|4.0|Another Outsource Marketing favorite! <br />Steve Krug couldn't have done a better job titling his book &quot;Don't Make Me Think: A Common Sense Approach to Web Usability.&quot; It's filled with common sense approaches that help website developers, writers, designers, and architects create sites that decrease cognitive load and telegraph ideas quicker. <br />He practices what he preaches: the graphics, layout and copy are brilliantly executed. Complex ideas are made simple with clear charts and graphs. Technical terms are written clearly so non-technical people will easily understand. And this excellent book is one of those rare quick reads with substance.<br />After reading this book, check out Jakob Nielsen's &quot;Designing Web Usability.&quot; The two books combined will give you a great foundational understanding of web usability.

0679428895|4.0|Robert Harris has perhaps achieved the impossible: he has turned a civil engineer into a sexy, swashbuckling hero. For that reason alone, he deserves four stars.<br />Marcus Attilius, is the new \\"Aquarius\\", the engineer in charge of the aqueducts, in the Bay of Naples circa AD 79. He comes from a family of honest engineers who have helped make the Aqueducts of the Roman Empire, the engineering marvel of their times. The description of these aqueducts and their structures is actually fascinating.<br />However, Attilius has a lot more to think about than how to build the next aqueduct. His predecessor mysteriously disappeared, he has had a run-in with the former slave who now runs Pompeii in the manner of Tony Soprano, he has fallen in love with this individual's daughter, and the water in many places has slowed to a drip. And we're not even getting into the fact that Vesuvius will erupt in a day or two.<br />Harris writes a thriller that is both fast-paced (Attilius traveling all over the area in a matter of hours) and SLOW-paced (to his credit, he makes you feel the excruciating pain as the lava dried second by second by second on individuals). He mixes true historic figures-Pliny the Elder, the Admiral/Poet, who wrote about Pompeii before he too was killed in the disaster-and fictional characters. <br />I would recommend this book to those who enjoy the historical thriller genre and don't demand too much (e.g., fully developed characters). It's a great read.

B0000DD7NL|4.0|I have to admit I was not a huge fan of Alicias debut, except for Fallin. Her second album, The Diary of Alicia Keys is a brilliant follow up that is a lot more funky and a little more soulful. Whereas her debut had mostly filler songs, this one has a ton of potential hits. Her soaring voice is in fine form as she belts out the ballads You Don't Know My Name and Slow Down. However, the best tracks on the album are her uptempo tracks. The opening track Karma is brilliant, and should be the next single. It's got a funky groove and a fiery vocal performance. Heartburn is very retro funk, and So Simple is Alicias first real venture into Hip-Pop. The only qualms I have about the cd, which are very minor, is that If I Ain't Got You is almost identical to Christina Aguilers Impossible, which Alicia wrote, right down to the and vocal gymnastics. When You Really Love Someone is also identical to Fallin. To me it's the exact same song, with different lyrics. With that said, though the songs are still strong. Overall, a remarkable second album which proves Alicia is only going to get better and better.

0375701427|3.0|I started this book with very high hopes - I'd only read one other Roth, the short and highly sarcastic \\"The Breast,\\" and I had heard that in recent years he'd turned more sober and objective.  To me this meant Roth was coming of age, a voice expressing a fuller range of our hopes, fears, loves and angers.<br />Much of \\"American Pastoral\\" satisfied this desire.  Book one (of three) is a 100-or-so page, somewhat tedious prologue, where Roth's alter ego Nathan Zuckerman intruduces the main character and creates a setting to present his secret story.  With book two, it settles into a wonderful exploration of inner and outer lives.  This central section, and most of book three, is beautifully written and reads effortlessly, making the first part feel worthwhile.  By combining real world places (hint - it helps a lot to know New Jersey) and politics, with fictional characters whose lives embody the times and themes, Roth puts us directly into the drama of the story.<br />This sounds like a clich; but through lengthy description, we learn by stages about the conflicts inside the main character.  Seymour \\"Swede\\" Levov, a handsome, Jewish industrialist and high school athletic hero who marries Dawn Dwyer, Miss New Jersey of 1949, and whose vigor and generosity of spirit bring him success in business and to a life in the affluent (and WASPish) Jersey countryside, suffers a tragic fall when his radical daughter Merry goes berserk with one murderous bombing, and then others.  As she begins a life on the run, he and Dawn endure recrimination and only-partial recovery.  We watch Swede in a journey through his past and his present, an apparently peaceful man who learns to accommodate the real world by devising his own reality.  This seems the central theme, just how we are to construct a world that we want to live in.  His traditional, Jewish father, and his angry brother, are respectively full of shame and hatred for the daughter, but Swede, who still wants to know what went wrong, is frozen - first in denial, later in incomprehension.<br />In the reading, we come to identify the people and the many facets of their predicament.  Yet in the end, the plot is dropped, and that's where it failed as a narrative.  American Pastoral ends symbolically and inconclusively.  We never learned Merry's ultimate fate, what happened to Swede's marriage, or even the real identity of Rita Cohen, the vicious young woman who may or may not have been Merry's accomplice.  I know it's a novel of ideas, but a book that goes to such trouble to develop characters and establish plot, should keep its promise and resolve the plot.  It made me wonder Why Roth went on at such length, in so many sections.  Why tell us the whole background to Swede and his family, and their latest heartbreaks, and then not finish the story?  If the point was simply to illustrate clashing symbols and themes, it could have been done much more economically.<br />American Pastoral won the Pulitzer Prize, I think largely on the strength of its exposition.  Much of it reads like an essay we'd want to write ourselves, from our very heart and soul, exploring our own tensions, flowing and unfolding with nervous honesty.  I wish those Pulitzer people cared more about story-telling, since this is how the greatest writers, Dickens, Melville, Twain, Nabokov, and others, truly touch our lives.
B000002LGQ|5.0|Madonna has graced my life in some interesting ways and this is one of them. I was never a huge Madonna fan, just an undercover one, one of my best friends had this CD and she made me listen it to it during our long bus rides to our &quot;in the boonies&quot; middle school, and sure enough I fell in love with this album and three years later I bought it.<BR>It's a very poetic album, lush and sophisticated and it hits some grounds that only Madonna could reach. <BR>The album starts with the major hit, &quot;Like A Prayer&quot; I remember this song, even though I was four when it came out, it has that gospel tinged feel to it with some pretty strong lyrics, it feels like Madonna has had the holy ghost! lol <BR>&quot;Express Yourself&quot;, my personal fave, Madonna has described as her Sly and The Family Stone tribute song. It's Prince!) but it's lacking something, probably my least favorite song on here, still it's Prince &amp; Madonna what more could you ask for? What famous pop singer talks about that kinda stuff? Madonna of course. A very enchanting song, the music video is cute too, it features Madonna as a cartoon fairy. On a serious note,&quot;Oh, Father&quot; is another special Madonna song, it's haunting with a sense of hurt and betryal. It really touches you to know what it felt like for Madonna being abused by her father. Another song that Madonna doesn't have to belt out, the words carry her through. &quot;Keep It Together&quot; has a jazzy/blusey feel too it with a strong message, staying together with family is important. It's not totally dancable but it livens up things. &quot;Spanish Eyes&quot; is another beautiful song, Madonna, like on &quot;La Isla Bonita&quot;, samples some Latin flavors to this song. I love the litte horn and guitar parts in the song. Beautifully done Madonna. &quot;Act of Contriction&quot; is just a little &quot;remix&quot; of &quot;Like A Prayer&quot; with Madonna praying and then screaming at the end, don't get it much...lol<BR>This is one of Madonna's shining moments, it hits alot of ground and proves that Madonna had something to offer, more than just frilly dresses and boy toy belts. This is one album to own and &quot;cherish&quot; for life. A true masterpiece.

B0000B1OFL|4.0|If you are a fan of hi-tech action films and love great chase scenes - \\"The Italian Job\\" is for you! Make a double batch of popcorn and settle in for a rollicking movie ride! The producers could have lost the script and speaking parts altogether - the action alone, along with the wicked sound track, would make many folks very happy. This tongue-in-cheek, super burglary, double-cross, murder, revenge thriller includes the grandmother and the mother of all chase scenes. There's a wild boat ride through the canals of Venice, and even wilder car chases, with the grand finale roaring through a Los Angeles train station, into tunnels, down stairs, with a wind-up duel between a Mini-Cooper and a helicopter. Charlize Theron looks svelte and sexy behind the wheel! If you are looking for a more cerebral film, then I'd advise you to rent something on the quieter side.<br />Donald Sutherland is terrific in a cameo as John Bridger, the sage guru among a band of hi-tech thieves plotting to steal millions in gold bullion from a safe in beautiful Venice. (Great photography!!) Bridger's protege, the outfit's mastermind, Charlie Croker, (played by Mark Wahlberg), along with his team, pull-off the heist without a hitch. After a spectacular get-away, the group drinks to success and future plans as wealthy men against the backdrop of the Swiss Alps. Then in the first twist, and there are more twists, turns, hitches and hikes in this one than in any amusement park ride, the evil-doing, back-stabbing, amoral Steve, (Ed Norton), turns on his fellow thieves. He heists the heist, murdering Bridger, and he believes, the rest of his mates.<br />Fast-forward one year and we find Bridger's daughter Stella, (Charlize Theron), a professional safe and vault technician (read safecracker), still mourning her Dad. Enter Dad's favorite sidekick, Charlie Croker, who proposes a plan for revenge to Stella. She buys in, along with old team members Napster, (Seth Green, who steals scene after scene), Handsome Rob (Jason Statham), and Left Ear (Mos Def) - very funny characters, all! They trek out to LA, where Steve has a new alias, high-end digs, guard dogs and body guards galore...and the GOLD! And they plan their ultimate payback!<br />I am not going to critique the acting or direction - I don't think this is what the film is about. There is nothing deep or meaningful here. It's just FUN! I am not a fan of action films. Chases, car and other, minimal acting and small plots are not my style - and I liked this movie! So, go know!? 6302491940|4.0|A double feature was recently offered on cable TV that allowed me to view \\"The Italian Job\\" twice - the 1969 version with Michael Caine and the 2003 version. The two films have little in common except a gold bullion robbery, 4 million dollars worth in 1969, and 27 million in 2003, to allow for the decreasing value of the dollar and bigger and better ways to spend it! I enjoyed the 2003 thriller but the older film is really an excellent comedy. I am so glad that I had the opportunity to see it, because I missed it, and lots of laughs, the first time around.<br />\\"The Italian Job\\" (1969) is a campy caper packed with 1960s nostalgia. There are enough gadgets and girls in this film to make even James Bond content, although Bond would never work with the bumbling, quirky characters that Michael Caine, called Charlie Croker here, is forced to deal with. The film opens with a choreographed hit by the Italian Mafia. The choreography could have been done for the June Taylor Dancers. It's a riot! Anyway, Roger Beckerman, a brilliant thief, is murdered because he had masterminded a potential heist to take place in Turin, Italy, involving millions of dollars of Chinese gold bullion. Beckerman leaves a tape for Charlie Croker, who has just been released from a British prison. The video tape, to be viewed in the event of Beckerman's death, explains the entire caper and offers Charlie the opportunity to do the job. Charlie gets the funding for the project from Mr. Bridger, played by a wonderfully comic Noel Coward. Bridger is an inmate of the prison where Charlie had spent the last few years and he rules the UK underworld like a king, from his jail cell, with guards and inmates paying him homage. Croker fights off the advances of gorgeous blondes with one hand while he uses the other to whip into shape his motley crew of screwball bandits.<br />The dialogue is hilarious at times, especially when the team of thieves, who seem to have a collective IQ of 75, go at each other like recalcitrant adolescent schoolboys. Croker who occasionally is forced to step out of his role as master-thief to play schoolmaster, yells at his men during a particularly delicate operation, \\"Get yourselves sorted out and shut-up! No one talks anymore except me!\\" During a meeting with the Mafia leader who threatens to kill Croker and his men if they pull-off the job, Charlie responds, \\"You will be making a grave error if you kill us. There are one-quarter million Italians in Britain and they will be made to suffer. Every restaurant, cafe, ice cream parlor, gambling den and nightclub in London, Liverpool and Glasgow will be smashed. Mr. Bridger will drive them into the sea!\\"<br />This film is pure fun with the mother of all car chases as the grand finale. Not to be missed!<br />JANAalcitrant adolescent schoolboys. B00005LB50|4.0|Whenever I pay 50+ bucks for an exhaustive box set, I feel obligated to look at the purchase with a far more discerning critical eye than standard 14 dollar CD purchase. It's hard to be forgiving when the retail price is so high. That being said, this 4 CD collection will be the best sounding Buffalo Springfield you will ever hear. Neil Young was the right person to supervise the remastering of this project and he has done a great service to fans who have patiently waited for years the remastering to be completed. Perfectionism may be a pain in the posterior, but at the end of the day, you have Neil Young to thank for the cleaning the collection of Springfield's master tapes. The master tapes were probably in pretty bad condition after 35 years on someone's shelf and remastering them was time consuming, labor intensive process.<br />Here's my complaint. The actual chronology may be correct but there is a confusing mix of demos, remixes, outakes and unreleased songs that destroy the continuity of the original three albums. &quot;Buffalo Springfield&quot;, &quot;Buffalo Springfield, Again&quot; and &quot;Last Time Around&quot; are the holy grail of our youth and should not be tampered with by anyone, even Neil Young. The order of the songs on those albums are so firmly imprinted in my subconscious mind that each time I hear a song out of order, I break out in a cold sweat, begin screaming, &quot;Revisionist history!!!&quot;, before the enevitable grand mal seizure strikes. We're talking about sacred ground here, Neil!!!<br />It would have been far better to present the first three Buffalo Springfied albums in separate jewel cases with the orginal order of songs and the original artwork, than parking a jumbled mess of demos on the same CDs as the final takes. A seperate CD of demos and outtakes would have been fine, or even putting the session outtakes and demos at the end of each original album. The format of this box set probably makes sense to Neil Young and the rest of Buffalo Springfield, but there is a baffling clutter of &quot;not ready for prime time&quot; material on the first three CDs. If there is a rhyme or reason to all this discontinuity, it's well kept secret from Buffalo Springfield fans.<br />The only one I can listen is the fourth CD which presents the &quot;Buffalo Springfield&quot; and &quot;Buffalo Springfield Again&quot; in the exact chrnological order of the original albums, but repeating most of the studio cuts that have already been presented in the previous three CDs...Huh??? For some inexplicable reason, &quot;Last Time Around&quot; isn't entirely presented. Or is it? B000002AGE|5.0|It has been fashionable to belittle fusion jazz as a precursor to the mind numbing smooth jazz that has found such a big audience among aging baby boomers. How quickly we forget that the Weather Report was a port of entry to the world of jazz for many of us. Sure; I would have stumbled onto Monk, Coltrane, Miles and the other jazz greats sooner or later, but the music of the Weather Report was a fast track course in learning to appreciate the masters of bop and early jazz. There was a time when the music of the Weather Report was highly controversial in both the jazz community and rock community. Jazz critics called fusion &quot;revisionist&quot; and uncomprehending rock fans walked out of Weather Report concerts branding their music as &quot;unlistenable&quot;. I recall a show in 1973 where at least half of the clueless concert goers walked out of a show opened by Fairport Convention. If you set aside your misgivings about the jazz fusion movement, you will be able to appreciate how well the music of 1977's &quot;Heavy Weather&quot; has aged over the years. Pound for pound, and ounce for ounce this best crew ever assembled to play under the banner of the Weather Report. There are other crucial albums by Weather Report but this is the one that we will all remember them by.

Walker).  This in not to say that his crap is true, on the other hand, his references will show that his points are invalid. A writer who sees a pointed finger as a throat-cutting gesture, who says the Madonna of the Rocks was painted for nuns instead of a lay confraternity of men, who claims that da Vinci received \\"hundreds of lucrative Vatican commissions\\" (actually, it was just one...and it was never executed) is simply unreliable.<br />He presents the Mona Lisa as an androgynous self-portrait when it's widely known to portray a real woman, Madonna Lisa, wife of Francesco di Bartolomeo del Giocondo. The name is certainly not - as Brown claims - a mocking anagram of two Egyptian fertility deities Amon and L'Isa (Italian for Isis). How did he miss the theory, propounded by the authors of The Templar Revelation, that the Shroud of Turin is a photographed self-portrait of da Vinci?<br />Much of Brown's argument centers around da Vinci's Last Supper, a painting the author considers a coded message that reveals the truth about Jesus and the Grail. Brown points to the lack of a central chalice on the table as proof that the Grail isn't a material vessel. But da Vinci's painting specifically dramatizes the moment when Jesus warns, \\"One of you will betray me\\" (John 13:21). There is no Institution Narrative in St. John's Gospel. The Eucharist is not shown there. And the person sitting next to Jesus is not Mary Magdalene (as Brown claims) but St. John, portrayed as the usual effeminate da Vinci youth, comparable to his St. John the Baptist. Jesus is in the exact center of the painting, with two pyramidal groups of three apostles on each side. Although da Vinci was a spiritually troubled homosexual, Brown's contention that he coded his paintings with anti-Christian messages simply can't be sustained.\\"<br />It is impossible for me to point out every amount of falseness in this book, however I urge anyone to research it and find out for yourself. B000002AGN|5.0|While I'm definitely a newbie to the jazz genre, I know greatness when I hear it, and The Dave Brubeck Quartet's Time Out definitely fits that description. Released in 1959, a pivotal year for jazz, alongside gems like Giant Steps, Kind Of Blue, and Mingus Ah Um, Time Out rids jazz of fixed 4/4 and 3/4 time and incorporates exotic rhythms used in a totally accessible and catchy way. Both students of musical theory and casual listeners can get into this West Coast jazz album with equal enjoyment.<br />The opening track Blue Rondo A La Turk clearly shows this. Its in 9/8, in the style of Turkish folk music. Upbeat and catchy, this is a classic composition that's been covered and reintrepreted eight ways till Sunday. Ditto Take Five, a number done in 5/4 and featuring both a wonderfully slinky sax line and a Joe Morello drum solo. Other tracks do not fail to enchant either--Strange Meadowlark is an elegant slow composition driven by Dave's fine piano playing, Kalthy's Waltz is a complex yet compulsively listenable piece done in quick waltz time, while Everybody's Jumpin' and Pick Up Sticks are 6/8 compositions that close the album on a high note.<br />The band, while not being ultra-talented, definitely works great as a cohesive unit. Dave Brubeck's piano gives the music its backbone, drummer Joe Morello and bassist Eugene Wright supply the swingin' rhythms, and Paul Desmond does a fine job on alto sax.<br />All in all, I'd say Time Out is the ideal place for the jazz newbie, not Miles' Kind Of Blue (which is beyond doubt a great album but not the greatest choice for a novice, contrary to popular belief). It swings, it grooves, and it appeals to both the diehard jazz musician and the uninitiated. Highest recommendation.

And something else for all you Bible scholars out there, I picked up on a lot of parallels between the Childlike Empress and the God the Father. This is especially evident when Falkor tells Atreyu about her on their way to The Ivory Tower. I enjoy the first half of the book most and my favorite part is when Atreyu and Ygramul hear Bastian's voice in the Land of the Dead Mountains. Overall I am disappointed that this often gets labeled as a children's fantasy book, because it can be read on a level that only critical thinking adults can understand.
B000002UA5|3.0|Ummagumma is a very unique Pink Floyd entry, and an overlooked one. It was released in 1969, in the height of their experimental period following the departure of madcap genius Syd Barrett. The Roger Waters-led band had yet to find its voice, and the acid-drenched muse of Syd hadn't quite left the building yet. In other words, Dark Side Of The Moon this is NOT. This is a lot closer to the works of Zappa and avante-garde composers than to their more conventional later work.<br />The live disk is conventional enough. Recorded during the Saucerful Of Secrets era, there's some great trippy, spaced-out jamming to be found here. Particularly of note is a loud, scary reworking of Careful With That Axe Eugene that opens up with a terrifying scream by Roger, and a version of Astronomy Domine with David Gilmour on vocals.<br />The studio disk, however, is a lot more daunting, random, and WEIRD. It is split between the four band members, with Gilmour, Mason, and Wright making long multi-part suites. The Narrow Way is a Gilmour piece with some very heavy, dirty proto-Black Sabbath guitarwork. Sysyphus sees Wright banging away on his keyboards  and making some really strange sound effects, and The Grand Visier's Garden Party is a Mason piece featuring layers upon layers of looped drums in an annoying collage of sorts, sometimes with a flute showing up. Waters gives us perhaps the best song on here with the sublimely atmospheric and laidback Grandchester Meadows.<br />Following that is one of the freakiest songs ever: Several Species Of Small Furry Animals Dwelling Together In A Cave And Grooving With A Pict. Yes, that's the actual title. And yes, it features an insane, incoherent Scotsman rambling over the sounds of many animal squeaks and sound effects that is both hilarious and inexplicably frightening. Worlds apart from the dour, dark Waters compositions of later Floyd, this should be played for friends at high volume just to see the looks on their faces.<br />Yep, a totally different Floyd this is, and it's not for everyone, especially not newbies. Buy their '70s albums (Meddle through The Wall) first before you even consider this, and even then proceed with caution. The band itself doesn't have a very high opinion of Ummagumma (or Atom Heart Mother for that matter), but fans of Zappa, Mr. Bungle, and other weird and isoteric bands should give this a look. After all, even if the studio material scares you, there's still a decent live album and a cool poster to be had.ally different Floyd this is, and it's not for everyone, especially not newbies. Buy their '70s albums (Meddle through The Wall) first before you even consider this, and even then proceed with caution. It's about exploration of space and mankind, carried by good dialogue, good ideas, and good acting. Unfortunately, the people at Paramount don't seem to share that view.<br />They promised us a &quot;Generation's Final Journey&quot;; a final journey for our beloved characters - Fine. The opening scene at the wedding even is quite touching. However, after this, everything wents downhill very fast. Worf's role has been reduced to that of a clown, getting sick of Romulan Ale and being concerned of showing up nude at a Betazed wedding. This character's main attributes used to be honor, valor, justice, and a constant struggle between Human and Klingon culture. Not so in Nemesis.<br />Worf? Wait a second... Worf? What is doing there anyway? Didn't the people at Paramount watch the ending of DS9? Why is Worf suddenly back on the Enterprise? Geez, that's the opposite of character development, really. In First Contact, Worf's appearance didn't feel forced at all. It was logical for him to fight there with the Defiant and being beamed aboard the Enterprise. In Nemesis, we don't even get to hear an explanation (I know, I should be grateful for this, since the explanation would have been hilarious anyway.)<br />Beverly, Riker and Geordi get nothing to do throughout the rest of the film. At least Deanna gets more screen time this time. As for Picard, his role is saved only by Stewart's brilliant acting, though Stewart obviously has a hard time fighting against the awful script. And THIS was the last time I've seen my beloved characters? Not how I had once pictured it. What a way to kill of my TNG crew.<br />The plot is essentially... well, boring. What do they fight for anyway? It all bodes down to killing the villain. Boy, they had the Romulans and did nothing with them. Instead, they invent another new redundant alien race. How imaginative. Besides, what about the Romulans from the series? They don't even mention Sela or Tomalak. Another huge disappointment for the fans.<br />In my phantasy, I picture an alternate Star Trek 10... The true ending of a generation, involving Romulans, Klingons, Cardassians and Vulcans. Perhaps a fight for peace in the quadrant, a fight for Earth, for Starfleet and the Federation. A new era of Star Trek. Something revolutionary. Important roles for every member of the cast. Much nostalgy, cameos for Sela, O'Brien, Ro Laren, and Pulaski perhaps? Continuity with the TV epsiodes and previous movies, Worf being Klingon ambassador, Data having emotions, and so on. A big epos combined with something imagantive and groundbreaking... like the invention of Warp 10 or anything. *sigh* Unfortunately, this is all just a dream now, and it won't happen anymore. Nemesis has absolutely nothing of what I just tried to describe. Nothing. It leaves you with such an empty feel in your stomache you almost want to cry.<br />I give it the second star only because non-fans will probably like the movie a bit more, because the special effects are good, because of the DVD extras, and because Goldsmith's score is very nice as well (albeit a bit repetitive, isn't it?). Can we just say it never happened, please?

B000089RVX|3.0|To be fair, this isn't my type of music. I like distortion as much as the next guy, but the metal edge was never really my thing. Something about this has me hooked, though, and the only thing that keeps me from giving it a fourth star is that the lyrics are pretty one-note: Amy's angry, but not too angry, because God is with her. <br />Amy Lee has a jaw-dropping voice, and that's not contestable. Throw in some vibrato and it's operatic. Joyously, she knows that she should use that voice instead of screaming like a stuck pig like so many other singers in this genre. She tends to sing at full volume all the time, whether or not we're at a high point in the song. I wish she used just a little bit more restraint in this regard, but if it were my debut album I'd want to show the world what I can do, too.<br />Ben Moody is a passable guitarist, whacking out the normal battery of drop-D power chords and wah-wah solos. I get the feel, though, that he's much more important to this band as a composer and a macho foil for Lee's siren songs.<br />What really makes this album is the production. This isn't widescreen, it's imax. The opening phrases of &quot;Going Under&quot; didn't make me especially hopeful, but the swaggering, stomping chorus hit about a minute in and the first thing I could thing was &quot;wow, there are guitars everywhere.&quot; Strings, synthesizers, and even some plaintive piano setting off the distortion-from-sea-to-shining-sea riffs: this is a masterpiece of production.<br />Oh, and about that piano: let's have more of it next time. The two piano ballads hiding in the later tracks take the listener completely off-guard and make the guitar blasts seem both excessive and ever more powerful. There's some seriously good composition going on here, and some intense interplay between instruments. These guys are good, and they have enormous potential. Maybe I'm hesitant to give this four stars because I'm leaving room for a better second album and a masterpiecethird.

B00004S6GL|5.0|A lot of fans like to dog this album.  I have a theory for why this is.<br />It's not that the album is bad, at all, but that it's not the Elliott that THEY want Elliott to be.  They fell in love with the man behind either/or, or the self-titled, or (gasp) the barely audible Roman Candle.  They swoon for the quietness, the starkness, the nakedness, bitterness, intimacy.  They think &quot;hi-fi&quot; is a four-letter word, not to mention &quot;production&quot;, and dare I even say it, &quot;pop.&quot;<br />They were willing to accept XO as a temporary stray from the purity of their vision for his career.  In their forgiving state of mind, the music was able to seep into their brains and they saw its brilliance.  Hence, XO = good.  And, surely Elliott will get back on track next time.<br />Figure 8 comes along and dashes their hopes.  Their beloved tortured soulmate actually knows his way around modern expensive studio technology - AND HE LIKES IT!!!  Traitor!<br />Man, I love E.S. and E/O as much as anyone.  Love em.  Love em love em love em.  But I'm one of those who believe that Elliott broke through into an altogether new plane of genius with XO.  And Figure 8 is absolutely a worthy continuation of the path he was on.<br />Put it this way - if I'm taking ten to the desert island, XO is in the bag for sure.  Figure 8 will be really, really hard to leave out.  The others, I'll miss a hell of a lot.
038572179X|1.0|I was anxious to read this book, as I love books about the second world war. Plus, this book had received so many accolades.<br />Well, what a major disappointment. This is no masterpiece, or what can even be considered a good book. Part I is so slow, that you are ready to fall asleep by the time the \\"big event\\" occurs. Also, while there is a main character, 13 year old Briony, we are given too many points of view. I kept thinking, come on, can we get on with the story.<br />Now, we have a young man accused of rape, witnessed by a 13 girl. Well, we never know if the woman was actually raped. She never gives her side of the story. And what happened at the trial? Duh, there is no trial. Nada, zilch. Because, then part II opens, and rather than picking up where we left off--with Robbie being taken away, accused of a crime--we are suddenly in the middle of the British retreat at Dunkirk. Page after page of battle descriptions. For what purpose? I began skipping and skipping, hoping to find the story. It seemed odd that part II would center around what was a very minor character, and completely leave out every single detail of his trial and how he ended up in prison. All we know is that he was in prison for the crime that Briony accused him of, and now he's free.<br />Then part III, we meet up again with Briony, who is just as unlikeable as she was in part I. Part III was probably the best of the lot, but you still haven't a clue as to what actually happened. Since when does a person go to prison on the basis of the testimony of a 13 year old girl--who wasn't even the victim!<br />The ending is about as ridiculous as it gets. We are supposed to believe that this whole story we just finished reading is really just a novel that Briony wrote. That's the \\"Clever\\" twist of it. All I can say is that I'm thankful I borrowed it from the library.<br />This is one of those books that is so full of itself, that it pretends to be great and monumentous, but in fact, is very poorly down. This is so much missing, and much of it is so cliche. It makes so much of the great crime, but the crime really isn't all that great because as far as I know, England does have a trial system. A person goes to prison after being put on trial, and not because an obnoxious 13 year old girl says so. We are never told anything at all about how Robbie ended up in prison, or if anyone defended him, or what the victim herself had to say. <br />I felt nothing for any of the characters, except for Briony, who I disliked intensely. This book is just a pompous work where the author writes pages of descriptions that go nowhere, tell you nothing, and leave you wondering when the story will begin.

0553582445|2.0|One damn thing after another happens to Fitz, fifteen years after the end of his previous adventures.  Neat low-tech survival details followed by romance-novel gushiness seemingly designed to pre-empt the slash writers, some court intrigue, action scene, action scene, character self-torture, action scene.  Dangers pile further and further on Fitz, but the whole thing is past-tense, so you know something amazingly convenient is going to get ratcheted in place just in time....    On the plus side, you no longer want to throttle the main character for his endless tortured internal conflicts---there's a _new_ character who's _worse_.  Also, what could have been a simple Good Guys/Bad Guys scenario is nicely complicated (here's a hint: what if ACT UP turned really nasty).    If you have a lot of free time, this is less of a waste of it than your second hour of web surfing, but more than your first.

B0000C6E4D|4.0|Sarah McLachlan has always been an artist who conveys complexity with simplicity, and \\"Afterglow\\" is a sparkling example of this precept.<br />While \\"Afterglow\\" does not pack the punch of Sarah's 1994 breakthrough release titled \\"Fumbling Through Ecstasy\\", which kicked off with the amazing \\"Possession\\", \\"Afterglow\\" is as touching and thoughtful as her best work. This release has received mixed reviews and while everyone's opinion should be respected, I think that some reviewers are being a little harsh as most of Sarah's work takes time to sink in. \\"Possession\\", while an AMAZING song, is the exception and not the rule in Sarah's approach to music but I too wish there were an equivalent punch here.<br />On this release Sarah's voice sounds as beautiful as ever and there is something so soothing to Sarah's music that it warms my soul and reminds me of the person who introduced me to Sarah. Thanks Curtis! Some reviewers have expressed the belief that all the songs sound the same and other were bored while others compare it to a diary of a high school girl, but I found this release to be quite cohesive and reflects the thoughts of a grown woman. One could argue that Sarah is not breaking any new ground with this release, but I still recommend it.<br />A lesser artist would have abandoned her amazing producer, included guest rapper/hip hop artists, and would have posed in a sexually provocative manner on the cover of this release. Sarah follows her own path and does not believe in making changes for the sake of change. If you are a Sarah fan and appreciate her subtlety, I highly recommed this release as long as you don't expect something vastly different from her previous efforts. My current favorites are \\"Fallen\\", \\"Stupid\\", \\"Time\\", and \\"Dirty Little Secret\\".

B000065V1V|5.0|Like an unfamiliar friend, Heathen's haunting sedition invites you into wanting to be more than just acquainted. After the first listen, the CD player was set to repeat as Heathen cycled four times, and then you're hopelessly hooked. This is not an easy accomplishment, yet David commands this ability so easily.  Though each track stands on its own, this is a package, each song a member of the family and shouldn't be orphaned.  This is such a seductively rich package, why would you want to listen to anything else once this disc starts?  All the superlatives have been said already and they're all not only appropriate, but there's certainly more that haven't even been invented yet for David.  In my 44 years, I have regarded The Beatles as the Paradigm of modern popular music recording artists; a gift.  \\"Musical Artist\\" is a title thrown around much too loosely these days.  David is not one to be ranked.  An artist simply is, and David is a gem to the world in this respect as well.  Will nothing slow this man's musical momentum down?  When I think of Bowie's \\"Pin-Ups\\" album and it's tribute to other band's great music, Heathen is a tribute unto himself, yet at the same time reveals a freshness that is unlike anything done prior.  This is modern music writing done the way it used to be, while continuously exploring new frontiers.  Everything you have ever enjoyed in Bowie's work from day one to present is here.  This is the best greatest hits album Bowie never did!   This man is so clever and has such ingenuity that while listening, you hear so many different shades of things by other people that might have done but never did, all the while sounding like no one but himself.  On \\"Slip Away\\" you are weaved through a time capsule that meshes Space Oddity meeting Procul Harum with a momentary smack of John Lennon's Jealous Guy.  This is not a musical comparison, just an eerie journey that visits emotional musical souls of the past.  \\"Everyone Says `Hi'\\" is so simplisticallyrich with charm that you just want to...hug someone!  It so prolifically captures the sincerest desire of reunification from the separation of a loved one that it bring tears and hopeful happiness all at the same time.  The opening track, \\"Sunday\\" opens with such power and emotion and from then on you begin a musical journey that you have no desire to return from until all too soon, the disc closes.  \\"Heathen (the rays)\\" is an ethereal closer.  A song of searching and enigmatic plea, which is very emotional, as all great closers are.  This CD is a real roller coaster that just glides you into each dynamic incline, dip and bend.  Top radio plays?  Unfortunately not, though as these capricious masterpieces deserve the attention of every proclaimed \\"music lover\\", only those fortunate enough to have the mind for genuine proficiency in classic/contemporary rock will be privileged enough to find this out.  David's musical genius, similar in a completely different way to the poignant cleverness of Roger Waters, commands a perfect work here.  If you are a follower of David's music, this is a must have.  If you are a self-proclaimed Bowie fan and find this any less than irresistible, I can't even imagine what you've been listening to all these years.  It's not Ziggy Stardust, it's not Hunky Dory, it's not Alladin Sane, Station To Station, Young Americans, Tin Machine, etc.  It's every single one of them.  As a bonus, Bowie manages to include the best stuff that even Peter Gabriel and Adrian Belew haven't done yet!  David's voice has never been better.  Never.  From delicate urgency to raw authority, David has never been in better control, of everything.  I shouldn't make absolutes here, and Bowie is as hard as it gets considering his enormously wonderful harvest of masterpieces, but if I could only have one...this is it.  This guy has never looked, or sounded better and is at the top of his game.  At this rate it's hard to conceive what he can do with another 30 years, but my guess is he will \\"Never Let You Down\\".
B0000DD7NL|5.0|After listening to Fallin' once, I became a huge Alicia Keys fan.  And then, after listening to Songs in A Minor I became an even huger fan.  I have to admit that I was worried about Alicia suffering that sophomore jinx, but after listening to Diary, I shouldn't have been.  Alicia has done a wonderful job of living up to the high standards of Songs. while the whole album is great, it's really the first 6 songs that really stand out: Karma (a lil hip hop flava to it), Heartburn (an addictive disco piece produced by Timbaland that is EXCELLENT!), If I Was Your Woman (a Gladys Knight remake with an urban beat), You Don't Know My Name (first single), If I Ain't Got You (a beautiful soulful song), and Diary (a very sweet, melodic song.)  All the rest of the songs are nice too, just not stand out songs like these first six.  Anyway, this album will definitely not disappoint you if you like listening to good music.
